{{italic title}} {{Thomism}}
'''''Contra errores Graecorum''', ad Urbanum IV Pontificem Maximum'' (''Against the Errors of the Greeks, to [[Pope Urban IV]]'') is a short treatise (an "opusculum") written in 1263 by [[Roman Catholic]] theologian Saint [[Thomas Aquinas]] as a contribution to Pope Urban's efforts at reunion with the [[Eastern Orthodox Church|Eastern Church]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=BWtarhaGxPUC&pg=PA167&dq=Aquinas+%22errores+graecorum%22&lr= Aidan Nichols, Discovering Aquinas: An Introduction to His Life, Work, and Influence] (Wm. B. Eerdmans Publishing, 2003 {{ISBN|0-8028-0514-0}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8028-0514-0}}), p. 167</ref> Aquinas wrote the treatise in 1263 while he was papal theologian and conventual lector in the Dominican ''studium'' at [[Orvieto]] after his first regency as professor of theology at the [[University of Paris]] which ended in 1259 and before he took up his duties in 1265 reforming the [[Dominican Order|Dominican]] ''studium'' at [[Santa Sabina]], the forerunner of the [[Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas|Pontifical University of Saint Thomas Aquinas, ''Angelicum'']], in Rome.
==Text==
The title of the treatise was not given by Aquinas himself, and it contains nothing that is directed against the doctrine of the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], but only, in the view of theologian [[Yves Congar]], a defence of Catholic doctrine against Eastern misunderstandings.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=CxucHPqvy5cC&pg=PA88&dq=Aquinas+%22errores+graecorum%22&lr=#PPA88,M1 Gabriel Flynn, Yves Congar: theologian of the church] (Peeters Publishers, 2005 {{ISBN|90-429-1668-0}}, {{ISBN|978-90-429-1668-5}}), p. 88</ref>
The 72 chapters of the work are each of the length of a paragraph in a modern book. In it Aquinas presents the teaching of the Greek Church Fathers as in harmony with that of the [[Latin Church]].<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=81vCJkNCb8kC&pg=PP1&dq=Davies+Aquinas#PPA5,M1 Brian Davies, Aquinas: an introduction] (Continuum International Publishing Group, 2004 {{ISBN|0-8264-7095-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8264-7095-9}}), p. 5</ref> The book is arranged in two parts, the first of 32 chapters and the second of 40, each part preceded by a prologue, and the work as a whole concluded with an epilogue. All the first part and 31 of the 40 chapters of the second concern [[Pneumatology (Christianity)|pneumatology]] (doctrine on the [[Holy Spirit]]). Of the final 9 chapters, 7 deal with the position of the [[Pope|Roman Pontiff]], and the last two with the use of leavened bread in the [[Eucharist]] and with [[purgatory]]. In all of these Aquinas quoted expressions by Fathers of the Greek Church in support of the teaching propounded by the Latin Church.
Aquinas died on his way to participate in the 1274 [[Second Council of Lyons]], to which he had been invited, but this treatise, which he had written eleven years before and not for the use of this Council,<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=_6PYWPWWhrUC&pg=PA196&dq=Aquinas+%22errores+graecorum%22&lr= Deno John Geanakoplos, Constantinople and the West: essays on the late Byzantine (Palaeologan) and Italian Renaissances and the Byzantine and Roman churches](Univ of Wisconsin Press, 1989 {{ISBN|0-299-11884-3}}, {{ISBN|978-0-299-11884-6}}), p. 196]</ref> was influential at the Council.
The 1968 Leonine edition is available in Latin at the [http://www.corpusthomisticum.org/oce.html Corpus Thomisticum website].
A complete English translation is given at the website of [https://web.archive.org/web/20090808081714/http://www.op-stjoseph.org/Students/study/thomas/ContraErrGraecorum.htm the Dominican Province of St Joseph].
A different English translation, but only of the first ten chapters, is found at the website of [https://web.archive.org/web/20080509054823/http://www.globalserve.net/~bumblebee/ecclesia/errorgre.htm Ecclesia Triumphans Catholic Apologetics].
==Contents==
The titles of the first ten chapters given in the latter translation indicate something of the contents of the short work: # How it should be understood when it is said that the Son comes from the Father as an effect from a cause (Quomodo intelligitur hoc quod dicitur quod filius habet a patre sicut causatum a causa). # How it should be understood when it is said that the Son is second, after the Father, and the Holy Spirit is third (Quomodo intelligitur cum dicitur, quod filius sit secundus a patre, et spiritus sanctus sit tertius). # How it should be understood when it is said that the Holy Spirit is the third light (Quomodo intelligitur hoc quod spiritus sanctus sit tertium lumen). # How it should be understood when it is said that essence is begotten in the Son, and spirated in the Holy Spirit (Quomodo intelligitur, quod essentia sit genita in filio, et spirata in spiritu sancto). # How it should be understood when it is said that Jesus is the Son of the Father's essence (Quomodo intelligitur quod Iesus dicitur filius paternae essentiae). # How it should be understood when it is said that what naturally belongs to the Father, naturally belongs to the Son (Quomodo intelligitur, quod quae sunt propria naturaliter patris, sunt propria filii). # How it should be understood when it is said that the perfection of the Father does not lack anything from either the Son or the Holy Spirit (Quomodo intelligitur quod pater neque filio neque spiritu sancto indiget ad sui perfectionem). # How it should be understood when the Holy Spirit is called unbegotten (Quomodo intelligitur quod spiritus sanctus dicatur ingenitus). # How it should be understood when the Holy Spirit is said to be the middle between the Father and the Son (Quomodo intelligitur quod spiritus sanctus dicitur medius patris et filii). # How it should be understood when it is said that the Holy Spirit is the image of the Son (Quomodo intelligitur hoc quod dicitur, quod spiritus sanctus sit imago filii).
In his treatise, Aquinas "demonstrated that there was a theological harmony between the Greek Church Fathers and the Latin Church".<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=f_jLbHTM_zgC&pg=PA39&vq=contra+errores+graecorum&source=gbs_search_r&cad=1_1 Jana K. Schulman, The rise of the medieval world, 500-1300: a biographical dictionary] (Greenwood Publishing Group, 2002 {{ISBN|0-313-30817-9}}, {{ISBN|978-0-313-30817-8}})</ref> He pointed out that one source of misunderstandings between Greeks and Latins was the difficulty of finding appropriate words in each language` with which to translate technical theological terms used in the other: :''Many things which sound well enough in [[Greek language|Greek]] do not perhaps, sound well in [[Latin]]. Hence, Latins and Greeks professing the same faith do so using different words. For among the Greeks it is said, correctly, and in a Catholic way, that the Father, Son and Holy Spirit are three ''hypostases''. But with the Latins it does not sound right to say that there are three ''substantiae'', even though on a purely verbal basis the term ''hypostasis'' in Greek means the same as the term ''substantia'' in Latin. The fact is, ''substantia'' in Latin is more frequently used to signify essence. And both we and the Greeks hold that in God there is but one essence. So where the Greeks speak of three ''hypostases'', we Latins speak of three ''personae'', as Augustine in the seventh book on the Trinity also teaches. And, doubtless, there are many similar instances.'' :''It is, therefore, the task of the good translator, when translating material dealing with the Catholic faith, to preserve the meaning, but to adapt the mode of expression so that it is in harmony with the idiom of the language into which he is translating. For obviously, when anything spoken in a literary fashion in Latin is explained in common parlance, the explanation will be inept if it is simply word for word. All the more so, when anything expressed in one language is translated merely word for word into another, it will be no surprise if perplexity concerning the meaning of the original sometimes occurs.''<ref>Prologue to ''Contra Errores Graecorum''</ref>
==The problem of the sources==
The apologetic impact of the work is limited, due to the fact that Thomas uses a collection of texts compilled by [[Nicholas of Crotone]] which contains doubtful attributions and personal glosses of the compiller that bent the text in direction of the Latin theology. According to Jean-Pierre Torell, "on four specific questions concerning the procession ''a filio'', the primacy of the pope, the Eucharistic celebration with unleavened bread, and purgatory, Thomas is clearly forced to rely more on the texts that are closer to Latin theology, when these are in fact glosses foreign to the Fathers."<ref>Saint Thomas Aquinas: the person and his work, Volume 1, p. 123</ref>

{{About|heraldry|the mathematical operation|division by two}} [[File:Hastings Emblem Vectorized.svg|right|thumb|Coat of arms of [[Hastings]], showing a partially '''dimidiated''' shield, where the front halves of the upper and lower lions are joined to the rear halves of ships. This motif features widely in the heraldry of the [[Cinque Ports]]]] [[File:POL Prochowice COA.svg|thumb|Horizontally dimidiated rabbit and fish, arms of the town and [[gmina]] of [[Prochowice]], SW Poland. Horizontal dimidiations are rare, if not unknown, in English heraldry]] [[File:Blason ville fr Les Andelys (Eure).svg|right|thumb|Coat of arms of the consolidated commune of [[Les Andelys]], dimidiated (French: ''Mi-parti'') per pale, three droops of grapes and three castle keeps. Dimidiations are rare in French heraldry.]] {{Heraldic achievement}} In [[heraldry]], '''dimidiation''' is a method of [[Heraldry#Marshalling|marshalling]] (heraldically combining) two [[coat of arms|coats of arms]].
For a time, dimidiation preceded the method known as [[Impalement (heraldry)|impalement]]. Whereas impalement involves placing the whole of both coats of arms side by side in the same shield, dimidiation involves placing the [[Dexter and sinister|dexter]] half of one coat of arms alongside the [[Dexter and sinister|sinister]] half of the other. In the case of marriage, the dexter half of the husband's arms would be placed alongside the sinister half of the wife's arms.
The practice fell out of use because the result was not always aesthetically pleasing (sometimes creating strange hybrids, as seen in the examples at right), and also because in some cases, it would result in a shield that confusingly looked like one coat of arms rather than a combination of two. For instance, a [[Bend (heraldry)|bend]] combined with a bend sinister might result in a combination that simply looked like a [[Chevron (insignia)|chevron]], thus hiding the fact that two coats of arms had been combined.
In order to avoid these drawbacks, it became customary to use more than half of each coat of arms when combining them through dimidiation. Once this practice had begun, the logical progression was to include the whole of both coats of arms in the new shield, so that in effect, impalement replaced dimidiation as a method of combining coats of arms.
A general rule which carries over from dimidiation to impalement is that if a coat of arms with a [[bordure]] (or [[tressure]], [[orle (heraldry)|orle]], etc.) is impaled, the bordure should not continue down the line of impalement.
<gallery> File:Dimidiation demo.svg|Example of two coats dimidiated File:Impalement demo.svg|The same two coats impaled File:Dimidiation, worse case demo.svg|When the ''dexter'' half of a ''bend sinister'' is dimidiated with the ''sinister'' half of a ''bend'', the result would look like a ''chevron'' File:Isabella of Scotland Arms.svg|Tressure does not continue down the line of impalement </gallery>

[[Jeanne Moreau]] | music = [[Peer Raben]] | cinematography = Elfi Mikesch | editing = Mike Shepard | studio = ZDF / ARTE | distributor = | released = {{film date|df=y|2000|11|10}} | runtime = 90 minutes | country = Germany | language = German | budget = | gross = $160,854 (USA) }} ''''' Fassbinder's Women''''' ([[German language|German]]: ''Für mich gab's nur noch Fassbinder - Die Glücklichen Opfer Des Rainer Werner F'') is a 2000 German [[documentary]] [[film]] directed by [[Rosa von Praunheim]]. The original German title translates as ''Fassbinder Was the Only One for Me: The Willing Victims of Rainer Werner F''.{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117798392/awards|title= Fassbinder's Women|publisher=Variety|accessdate=2012-06-12}} The film consists of several interviews with the women who part of the professional and personal lives of the German film director [[Rainer Werner Fassbinder]]. These include: [[Hanna Schygulla]], the director's favorite actress; Ursula Strätz, who founded the Munich Action Theater, where Fassbinder began his career on the stage and actresses [[Barbara Valentin]] and [[Brigitte Mira]], the star of Fassbinder’s ''[[Fear Eats the Soul]]''.{{cite news | last = Anderson | first = Melissa | title = The Films of Rosa von Praunheim at Anthology | work =[[The Village Voice]] | date = June 3, 2009 | url = http://www.villagevoice.com/2009-06-03/film/the-films-of-rosa-von-praunheim-at-anthology/ | accessdate = 2014-05-05 }} Four of the director’s male collaborators: assistant director [[Harry Baer]]; cinematographer [[Michael Ballhaus]]; musician [[Peer Raben]] and producer Peter Berling, also talk about Fassbinder's working methods and personality. The film opens with actress [[Irm Hermann]], who worked in nineteen films with Fassbinder while he made life a living hell for her. [[Juliane Lorenz]], Fassbinder’s last female partner, film editor and executor of his estate after his death, is also interviewed. Fassbinder’s ex-wife, actress and singer [[Ingrid Caven]], briefly talks about him in a phone conversation. Missing from the lineup are onscreen collaborators [[Margit Carstensen]] and [[Barbara Sukowa]]. There are no clips from Fassbinder’s films.{{cite web|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117798392/revied|title= Fassbinder's Women|publisher=Variety|accessdate=2012-06-12}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|id=0265197 |title= Fassbinder's Women }} [[Category:Films directed by Rosa von Praunheim]] [[Category:Documentary films about film directors and producers]] [[Category:2000 films]] [[Category:German films]] [[Category:2000s documentary films]] [[Category:Documentary films about women]] {{2000s-Germany-film-stub}} {{documentary-film-stub}}

[[File:Songhuizong4.jpg|300px|thumb|''Golden Pheasant and Cotton Rose Flowers with Butterflies'' (11th century) by [[Emperor Huizong of Song]]]]
'''''Gongbi''''' ({{Zh|t=工筆|s=工笔|p=gōng bǐ|w=kung-pi}}) is a careful [[Realism (arts)|realist]] technique in [[Chinese painting]], the opposite of the interpretive and freely expressive ''[[Xieyi (painting)|xieyi]]'' (寫意 'sketching thoughts') style.
The name is from the Chinese ''gong jin'' meaning 'tidy' (meticulous brush craftsmanship). The ''gongbi'' technique uses highly detailed brushstrokes that delimits details very precisely and without independent or expressive variation.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Gongbi Painting - Chinese Traditional Painting with Meticulous Detail - China culture Qiu Ying, Shen Quan|url = http://arts.cultural-china.com/en/62Arts2192.html|website = arts.cultural-china.com|access-date = 2016-02-04|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090409090447/http://arts.cultural-china.com/en/62Arts2192.html|archivedate = 2009-04-09|df = }}</ref> It is often highly colored and usually depicts figural or narrative subjects.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = gongbi {{!}} Chinese painting|url = http://www.britannica.com/art/gongbi|website = Encyclopædia Britannica|access-date = 2016-02-04}}</ref> One of the better known Gongbi works is the Song Dynasty Scroll, 17 feet long and includes intricate details that most don’t pick up. It is one of many popular tourist attractions in China today, as it is updated regularly to try and show what modern China looks like compared to when it was created during the Song Dynasty.<ref>{{cite web |title=Two Versions of the Scroll |url=http://afe.easia.columbia.edu/songdynasty-module/intro-two-versions.html |website=The Song Dynasty in China: China in 1000 CE |publisher=Columbia University |accessdate=17 October 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
The term related to ''gongbi'', ''jiehua'' (or "boundary painting"), refers to the accurate depiction of [[architectural]] forms aided by the ruler.<ref name=":0" />
==History== The ''gongbi'' style had its beginnings approximately 2000 years ago during the [[Han dynasty]] (206 BC – 220 AD) when Han's political stability and its prosperity favored the advancement of the arts. These paintings peaked out between the [[Tang dynasty|Tang]] and [[Song dynasty|Song]] dynasties (7th to 13th centuries) when these refined paintings were endorsed and collected by the royal families of China. To perfect this style the ''gongbi'' artists must totally commit themselves to these techniques. Only the wealthy could afford such artists. This style of art was accomplished in secret in royal palaces and private homes. Gongbi is one of the oldest Chinese painting techniques that feature narratives or high authority figures in them.
==Tools== When using brushes to paint gongbi, there are specific types for contouring and colouring. There are four types of brushes for [[contour drawing|contouring]]; Hong Mao (red hairs), are used to draw thick strokes mainly for [[landscape]] and background visuals. Yi Wen is used for longer lines to paint clothing, for example. Ye Jing brushes are used to contour flowers and bedsheets. Xie Zhua is the finest contour brush used to paint strokes of dragonflies and specific detail in the painting. There are three sizes of brushes used to colour the surface of the painting: Da Bai Yun (large white cloud), Zhong Bai Yun (average white cloud) and Xiao Bai Yun (small white cloud). Rough drafts are usually drawn on [[rice paper]]. If there is only one draft, a special type of paper called [[Xuan paper]] is used. The soft paper is able to absorb water well, best used for [[Chinese painting]] and [[calligraphy]].<ref name=":1">http://www.chine-culture.com/en/chinese-painting/chinese-painting-gongbi.php; retrieved on 2014-04-3</ref> Silk can also be used, which is sized as well.
==Process of the craft== ''Gongbi'' requires drawing with fine lines first to represent the exaggerated likenesses of the objects, and then adds washes of ink and color layer by layer, so as to approach the perfection of exquisiteness and fine art. The practice of Gongbi is specifically on rice paper when sketching out the design and layout of the drawing. Typically, pencil is used before beginning the second draft with the tipped brushes. The variation and detail in strokes are important especially when layering each wash of ink on top of each other. There are upward and downward strokes used that emphasize detailed pictures such as facial features and insects.<ref name=":1" /> After hundreds of years, a technique was developed for all gongbi artists as a system. Lines are used first to contour the figure and determine the fine outlines of the painting. Modest colors are added to the painting that add onto a sense of nature; flamboyant colors are used when the content of the painting has accentuated lines.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chinaculture.org/classics/2012-02/10/content_429449_2.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407095336/http://www.chinaculture.org/classics/2012-02/10/content_429449_2.htm |archivedate=2014-04-07 |df= }} retrieved on 2014-04-3</ref>
==''Gongbi'' painters== Listed chronologically: * [[Yan Liben]] (c. 600–673) * [[Zhang Xuan]] (713–755) * [[Zhou Fang (Tang dynasty)|Zhou Fang]] (c. 730–800) * [[Gu Hongzhong]] (937–975) * [[Emperor Huizong of Song]] (1082–1135) * [[Tang Yin]] (1470–1524) * [[Qiu Ying]] (1494–1552) * [[Chen Hongshou]] (1598–1652)

[[File:Hilye-i serif 1.jpg|thumb|A ''hilye'' by [[Hâfiz Osman]] (1642–1698), who established the standard layout used for this type of [[calligraphic]] panel]] The term '''''hilya''''' ([[Arabic language|Arabic]] حلية (plural: ''ḥilan'', ''ḥulan''), {{lang-tr|hilye}} (plural: ''hilyeler'') denotes both a visual form in [[Ottoman art]] and a religious genre of [[Turkish literature#Ottoman literature|Ottoman Turkish literature]], each dealing with the [[physical description of Muhammad]]. Hilya literally means "ornament".
They originate with the discipline of ''shama'il'', the study of Muhammad's appearance and character, based on [[hadith]] accounts, most notably [[Tirmidhi]]'s ''al-Shama'il al-Muhamadiyyah wa al-Khasa'il al-Mustafawiyyah'' ("The Sublime Characteristics of Muhammad").
In Ottoman-era [[folk Islam]], there was a belief that reading and possessing Muhammad's description protects the person from trouble in this world and the next, it became customary to carry such descriptions, rendered in fine [[Islamic calligraphy|calligraphy]] and [[Ottoman illumination|illuminated]], as [[amulet]]s.<ref name="Bakker2009">{{cite book |title= The challenge of the silver screen: an analysis of the cinematic portraits of Jesus, Rama, Buddha and Muhammad |last= Bakker |first= Freek L.|authorlink= |year= 2009 |publisher= BRILL |location= |isbn= 978-90-04-16861-9 |page= 209 |pages= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=4KNSp-uEO18C&pg=PA209 |accessdate=}}</ref><ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998"/> In 17th-century [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] [[Turkey]], ''hilyes'' developed into an art form with a standard layout, often framed and used as a wall decoration. [[File:Hilye Yesarizade Mustafa Izzet Efendi.JPG|thumb|19th-century hilye on gilded and framed panel.]]
Later ''hilyes'' were also written for the [[Rashidun|first four Caliphs]], the [[Sahabah|companions of Muhammad]], Muhammad's grandchildren ([[Hasan ibn Ali|Hasan]] and [[Hussein ibn Ali|Hussein]]) and Islamic saints ([[wali]]s).
== Origins in hadith == {{main|Shama'il Muhammadiyah}} ''Hilye'', both as the literary genre and as the graphic art form, originates from ''shama'il'', the study of Muhammad's appearance and character. The best source on this subject is considered to be Imam [[Tirmidhi]]'s ''al-Shama'il al-Muhamadiyyah wa al-Khasa'il al-Mustafawiyyah'' ("The Sublime Characteristics of Muhammad"). The acceptance and influence of this work has led to the use of the term ''"shama'il"'' (appearance) to mean Muhammad's fine morals and unique physical beauty. As they contained hadiths describing Muhammad's spirit and physique, ''shama-il'' have been the source of ''hilye''. The best known and accepted of these hadith are attributed to his son-in-law and cousin [[Ali]].<ref name="Brockopp2010">{{cite book |title= The Cambridge companion to Muhammad |last= Brockopp |first= Jonathan E. |authorlink= |year= 2010 |publisher= Cambridge University Press |location= |isbn= 978-0-521-71372-6 |page= 130 |pages= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=o58K2t344YQC&pg=PA130 |accessdate=}}</ref> The sources of ''hilye'' have been the six main hadith books along with other hadith sources, attributed to people such as [[Aisha]], [[`Abd Allah ibn `Abbas]], [[Abu Hurairah]], [[Hasan ibn Ali]]. While ''shama'il'' lists the physical and spiritual characteristics of Muhammad in detail, in ''hilye'' these are written about in a literary style.<ref name="Erdogan">{{cite journal|journal=Cumhuriyet Üniversitesi İlahiyat Fakültesi Dergisi | author= Erdoğan, M. | title= Hâkim Mehmed Efendi'nin Manzum Hilyesi | volume= 11 |pages= 317–357| year= 2007| url= http://eskidergi.cumhuriyet.edu.tr/makale/1514.pdf | language = Turkish }}</ref>
Among other descriptive ''Shama'il'' text are the ''Dala'il al-Nubuwwah'' of [[Al-Bayhaqi]], ''Tarih-i Isfahan'' of Abu Naeem Isfahani, ''Al-Wafa bi Fadha'il al-Mustafa'' of [[Abu'l-Faraj ibn al-Jawzi]] and ''Al-Shifa'' of [[Qadi Ayyad]] are the main shemaa-il and hilya books.<ref name="Erdogan"/>
==Literary genre== Although many ''hilyes'' exist in Turkish literature, Persian literature does not have many examples of the ''shama'il'' and ''hilye'' genre. Abu Naeem Isfahani wrote a work titled ''Hilyetü'l-Evliya'', but it is not about Muhammad. For this reason, the ''hilye'' is considered one of Turkey's national literary genres.<ref name="Erdogan"/> Turkish literature has also some early works that may have inspired the appearance of the ''hilye'' as a literary genre. The ''Vesiletü'n-necat'' of [[Süleyman Çelebi (poet)|Süleyman Çelebi]] (1351-1422 [[:fr:Suleyman Çelebi (de Bursa)]]), and the ''Muhammeddiye'' of [[Yazıcıoğlu Mehmed]], referred to Muhammad's characteristics.<ref name="Yazar">{{cite journal | journal= Journal of Turkish Studies | author= Yazar, S. | title= Seyyid Şerîfî Mehmed Efendi ve Hilyesi (Seyyid Sherîfî Efendi and His Hilye) | volume= 2 | pages= 1026–1044 | year= 2007 | url= http://www.egirdir.net/SeyyidMehmed.pdf | language= Turkish | deadurl= yes | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140413170136/http://www.egirdir.net/SeyyidMehmed.pdf | archivedate= 2014-04-13 | df= }}</ref>
A 255-verse long ''Risale-i Resul'' about the attributes of Muhammad, written by a writer with the penname of Şerifi, was presented to [[Shahzade Bayezid]], one of the sons of [[Suleiman the Magnificent]], at an unknown date that was presumably before the Shahzade's death in 1562.<ref name="Erdogan"/> This is believed to be the earliest ''hilye'' in verse form in Turkish literature.<ref name="Yazar"/> However, the ''Hilye-i Şerif'' by [[Mehmet Hakani]] (d. 1606–07) is considered the finest example of the genre (see section below).<ref name=Gruber132>{{cite book |title= The Islamic manuscript tradition: ten centuries of book arts in Indiana University collections |last= Gruber |first= Christiane J. |authorlink= |year= 2010 |publisher= Indiana University Press |location= |isbn= 978-0-253-35377-1 |pages=131–133 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=lIY0oAd6Y40C&pg=PA132}} </ref><ref>Hilye-i Şerif, [https://archive.org/details/hilyeihakani00hakauoft Digitised copy] of the 1898 edition at [[archive.org]]</ref> The first ''hilye'' written in prose form is ''Hilye-i Celile ve Şemail-i 'Aliye'' by [[Hoca Sadeddin Efendi]].<ref name="Yazar"/>
Although the ''hilye'' tradition started with descriptions of Muhammad, later ''hilyes'' were written about the [[Rashidun|first four Caliphs]], the [[Sahabah|companions of Muhammad]], Muhammad's grandchildren ([[Hasan ibn Ali|Hasan]] and [[Hussein ibn Ali|Hussein]]) and Islamic saints ([[walis]]) such as [[Rumi|Mevlana]].<ref name="Yazar"/> The second most important ''hilye'', after Hakani's, is considered to be Cevri İbrahim Çelebi's ''hilye'', ''Hilye-i Çihar-Yar-ı Güzin'' (1630), about the physical appearance of the first four caliphs.<ref name="Erkal1999">{{cite journal | journal= Atatürk Üniversitesi Türkiyat Araştırmaları Enstitüsü Dergisi | issue= 12 | pages= 111–131 | year= 1999| title= Türk Edebiyatında Hilye ve Cevri'nin "Hilye-i Çâr Yâr-ı Güzin"i | author=Erkal, A. | url= http://e-dergi.atauni.edu.tr/index.php/taed/article/viewFile/1784/1783 | language = Turkish }}</ref> Another important ''hilye'' writer is Nesati Ahmed Dede (d. 1674), whose 184-verse long poem is about the physical characteristics of [[Prophets in Islam|14 prophets]] and [[Adam]].<ref name="Erkal1999"/> Other notable ''hilyes'' are Dursunzâde Bakayi's ''Hilye'tûl-Enbiya ve Çeyar-ı Güzîn'' (hilye of the prophet and his four caliphs), Nahifi's (d. 1738) prose ''hilye'' ''Nüzhet-ûl-Ahyar fi Tercüment-iş-Şemîl-i'' and Arif Süleyman Bey's (1761) ''Nazire-î Hakânî''.<ref name="velioglu">{{cite web|title=Hilye-i Şerif |author=Velioğlu, A.K. |work=Klasik Türk Sanatları Vakfı |accessdate=2012-01-18 |url=http://www.klasikturksanatlarivakfi.com/indexalt.php?sayfa=fotograf&fotokateid=40 |language=Turkish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101110205152/http://www.klasikturksanatlarivakfi.com/indexalt.php?sayfa=fotograf&fotokateid=40 |archivedate=2010-11-10 |df= }}</ref>
''Hilyes'' can be written as standalone prose or poems (often in the [[Masnavi (poetic form)|masnavi]] form). They can also be part of two other forms of Turkish Islamic literature, a Mevlid (account of Muhammad's life) or a ''Mir'aj-name'' (accounts of Muhammad's [[Isra and Mi'raj|Night Journey]]).<ref name="ispirli"/>
==Art form== [[File:PQ Khalili hilye mss 0759.JPG|thumb|right|A ''hilye'' (1712) meant to be folded and carried on one's person (the crease lines are visible). The two crescents above and below the large circle in the middle contain the description of Muhammad. The central circle describes the protective powers of the ''hilye''. The protective hand of [[Fatimah]] is also drawn on the lower crescent, as another sign against evil. The circle and the edges of the sheet are bordered with [[Koran]]ic verses. ]] While writers developed ''hilye'' as a literary genre, calligraphers and illuminators developed it into a decorative art form. Because of their supposed protective effect, a practice developed in Ottoman Turkey of the 17th century of carrying Muhammad's description on one's person.<ref name="baycol">{{cite journal| title= Hilye-i Şerifler ve Medeniyetimizdeki Yeri | author= Bayçöl, H.| year= 2007 | journal= Yağmur | issue= 37| volume= | pages= | url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/71303374/Hat-Sanat%C4%B1nda-Hilye-i-%C5%9Eerif-U%C4%9Fur-DERMAN | language = Turkish }}</ref> Similarly, because of the belief that a house with a ''hilye'' will not see poverty, trouble, fear or the devil,<ref name="Erdogan"/> such texts came to be displayed prominently in a house. The term of '''hilye''' was used for the art form for presenting these texts.<ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998"/> Thus, the ''hilye'', as a vehicle for Muhammad's presence after his death, was believed to have a [[talisman]]ic effect, capable of protecting a house, a child, a traveller, or a person in difficulty.<ref name=Gruber132 /> In addition, the purpose of the ''hilye'' is to help visualize Muhammad as a mediator between the sacred and human worlds, to connect with him by using the viewing of the ''hilye'' as an opportunity to send a traditional blessing upon him, and to establish an intimacy with him.<ref name=Gruber132 /><ref name=Zakariya/><ref name="Safi2009"/>
The pocket ''hilyes'' were written on a piece of paper, small enough to fit in a breast pocket after being folded in three. The folding lines were reinforced with cloth or leather. Other pocket ''hilyes'' were made of wood.<ref name="derman"/> ''Hilyes'' to be displayed on a wall were prepared on paper mounted on wooden panels, although in the 19th century, thick paper sheets became another medium.<ref name="derman"/> The top part of ''hilyes'' that were laid on wooded panels were carved and cut out in the form of a crown. The crown part would be richly illuminated and miniatures of Medina, the [[Al-Masjid al-Nabawi|tomb of Muhammad]] or the [[Kabaa]] would be placed there, together or separately.<ref>{{cite web| title= Hilye-i Şerife| author= Faruk Taşkale| url= http://www.faruktaskale.com/hilye-i-serife-the-charactrestics-of-the-prophet-muhammed | accessdate= 2012-01-20 | language = Turkish }}</ref>
Ottoman Turks have commissioned scribes to write ''hilyes'' in fine calligraphy and had them decorated with illuminators. Serving as a textual portraits of the prophets, ''hilye'' panels have decorated homes for centuries. These calligraphic panels were often framed and came to be used as wall decorations in houses, [[mosque]]s and shrines, fulfilling an equivalent role to that played by images of Jesus in the Christian tradition.<ref name="Safi2009">{{cite book |title= Memories of Muhammad: why the Prophet matters |last=Safi |first= Omid |authorlink= Omid Safi |year= 2009 |publisher= HarperCollins |location= |isbn= 978-0-06-123134-6 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=Gs2oDbagvfIC |accessdate=}}</ref>{{rp|276}}<ref name="Peters2010">{{cite book |title= Jesus and Muhammad: Parallel Tracks, Parallel Lives |last= Peters |first= F. E. |authorlink= |year= 2010 |publisher= Oxford University Press |location= |isbn= 978-0-19-974746-7 |pages= 160–161 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=olEi-1LZYYQC&pg=PA160 |accessdate=}}</ref> As symbolic art, they provided an aesthetically pleasing reminder of Muhammad's presence without involving the type of "graven image" unacceptable to most Muslims' sensitivities.<ref name="Ernst2004" /> Although not common,<ref>Another example of a triptych-like ''hilye'' is at: {{cite web|publisher=Museum With No Borders| title= Triptych with 'hilya-i-sherif' (noble description)|author=Paola Torre | accessdate=2012-01-27|url=http://www.discoverislamicart.org/database_item.php?id=object;ISL;it;Mus01;3;en}}</ref> some ''hilyes'' show the influence of [[Orthodox Christian]] icon-making because they are made like [[triptych]]s with foldable side panels.
The first recorded instance of Hilye-i Sherif panels is generally believed to have been prepared by the notable scribe [[Hâfiz Osman]] (1642–1698).<ref name="derman"/> He was one of earliest scribes known to make such works, although it has been suggested that another famous scribe, [[Ahmed Karahisarî]] (1468–1556), may have created one ''hilye'' panel about a century before.<ref>{{cite journal| author=Abdulkadiroğlu, A.| title=İlk Hilye Hattatı Ahmed Karahisari mi? (Is Ahmed Karahisaru the first hilye calligrapher?) | journal=Milli Kültür | issue=82 | pages= 48–52| year= 1991 | language = Turkish }} cited by {{cite journal|journal=Journal of Turkish Studies |author=Yazar, S. |title=Seyyid Şerîfî Mehmed Efendi ve Hilyesi (Seyyid Sherîfî Efendi and His Hilye) |volume=2 |pages=1026–1044 |year=2007 |url=http://www.egirdir.net/SeyyidMehmed.pdf |language=Turkish |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413170136/http://www.egirdir.net/SeyyidMehmed.pdf |archivedate=2014-04-13 |df= }}</ref> Hafız Osman was known to have experimented with pocket ''hilyes'' in his youth, one of these dates from 1668. Its text was written in very small ''[[Naskh (script)|naskh]]'' script and has dimensions of 22x14 cm. It consisted of a description of Mohammad in Arabic, and below that its Turkish translation, written in diagonal, to create a triangular block of text.<ref name="derman">{{cite journal| title= Hat Sanatında Hilye-i Şerif | author= Derman, M.U.| year= 2000 | journal= Diyanet: İlmî Dergi | volume= | pages= | url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/71303374/Hat-Sanat%C4%B1nda-Hilye-i-%C5%9Eerif-U%C4%9Fur-DERMAN | language = Turkish }}</ref>
A characteristic feature of the texts shown at the centre of ''hilyes'' is their praise for the beauty of Muhammad's physical appearance and character.<ref name="Safi2009"/>{{rp|273–274}} While containing a verbal description of what Muhammad looked like, a ''hilye'' leaves picturing Muhammad's appearance to the reader's imagination, in line with the [[aniconism in Islam|mainly aniconic nature of Islamic art]].<ref name="Peters2010" />
===Standard layout=== The standard layout for the Ottoman ''hilye'' panel is generally attributed to [[Hâfiz Osman]]. This layout is generally considered to be the best and has come to be the classical form.<ref name="velioglu"/> It contains the following elements:<ref name=Gruber132/> [[File:Hilye-i Serif 6.jpg|thumb|left|Hilye by [[Kazasker Mustafa Izzet Efendi]] (1801–1876)]] *The ''baş makam'' ("head station"), a top panel containing a ''[[bismallah]]'' or blessing<ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998">{{cite book |title= Letters in gold: Ottoman calligraphy from the Sakıp Sabancı collection, Istanbul |last= Derman |first= M. Uğur |authorlink= |year= 1998 |publisher= Metropolitan Museum of Art (New York, N.Y.); Los Angeles County Museum of Art |location= |isbn= 978-0-87099-873-7 |page=36 |pages= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=mPTqAAAAMAAJ |accessdate=}}</ref> *The ''göbek'' ("belly"), a round shape containing the first part of the main text in ''naskh'' script.<ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998"/><ref name=Osborn/> It often contains the description of Muhammad by [[Ali]] (according to [[Tirmidhi]]), with minor variations<ref name="Schick">{{cite journal| author= Shick, I.C. | year= 2008 | title=The Iconicity of Islamic Calligraphy in Turkey | journal= RES: Anthropology and Aesthetics | issue=53/54 | pages= 211–224 | jstor= 25608818 }}</ref>(see quote in the [[#Origins|Origins]] section above). *The ''hilâl'' ("[[crescent]]"), an optional section with no text, which is often [[gilding|gilded]]. A crescent encircling the ''göbek'', with its thick middle part at the bottom. Together, the ''göbek'' and ''hilal'' also evoke the image of the sun and the moon.<ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998"/><ref name=Osborn/> *The ''kösheler'' ("corners"), usually four rounded compartments surrounding the ''göbek'', typically containing the names of the four ''[[Rashidun]]'' or "rightly-guided" [[Caliph]]s according to [[Sunnis]], or in some cases other titles of Muhammad, names of his companions, or some of the names of [[Allah]].<ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998"/><ref name=Osborn/> *The ''ayet'' or ''kuşak'' ("verse" or "belt") section below the ''göbek'' and crescent, containing a verse from the [[Quran]], usually {{cite quran|21|107|b=n|style=ref}} ("And We [God] did not send you [Muhammad] except to be a mercy to the universe"), or sometimes {{cite quran|68|4|b=n|style=ref}} ("Truly, you [Muhammad] are of a tremendous nature") or {{cite quran|48|28–29|b=n|style=ref}} ("And God is significant witness that Muhammad is the messenger of God").<ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998"/><ref name=Osborn/> *The ''etek'' ("skirt" or lower part) containing the conclusion of the text begun in the ''göbek'', a short prayer, and the signature of the artist. If the main text fits completely in the ''göbek'', the ''etek'' may be absent.<ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998"/> *The ''koltuklar'' ("empty spaces"), two alleys or side panels on either side of the ''etek'' that typically contain ornamentation – sometimes illuminated – but no text, although occasionally the names of some of the ten companions of Muhammad are found there.<ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998"/><ref name=Osborn/> *The ''iç'' and ''dış pervaz'' ("inner and outer frame"), an ornamental border in correct proportion to the text.<ref name=Osborn>{{cite book |title= The type of calligraphy: Writing, print, and technologies of the Arabic alphabet |last= Osborn |first= J. R. |authorlink= |year= 2008 |publisher= ProQuest |location= |isbn= 978-0-549-51769-6 | pages=236–239 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=YtQeZt7ybjwC&pg=PA238 |accessdate=}}</ref>
The remainder of the space is taken up with decorative [[Ottoman illumination]], of the type usual for the period, often with a border framing the whole in a contrasting design to the main central field that is the background of the text sections. The "verse" and "corners" normally use a larger ''[[thuluth]]'' script, while the "head" section with the ''bismallah'' is written in ''[[muhaqqaq]]''.<ref name=Ali8> {{cite journal| author = Ali, Wijdan| year = 2001| title = From the Literal to the Spiritual: The Development of the Prophet Muhammad's Portrayal from 13th Century Ilkhanid Miniatures to 17th Century Ottoman Art| volume = IV| pages = 1–24| publisher = EJOS (Electronic Journal of Oriental Studies) | url = http://www.staff.science.uu.nl/~gent0113/islam/downloads/ejos_4_7.pdf}}</ref> Unlike the literary genre of ''hilye'', the text on calligraphic ''hilyes'' is generally in prose form.<ref name="baycol"/>
The names in Turkish of the central structural elements of the ''hilye'' are, from top to bottom, ''başmakam'' (head station), ''göbek'' (belly), ''kuşak'' (belt) and ''etek'' (skirt). This [[anthropomorphic]] naming makes it clear that the ''hilye'' represents a human body, whose purpose is "to recall semantically the Prophet's presence via a graphic construct".<ref name="Gruber">{{cite book| author=Gruber, Christiane J. | title= The Islamic manuscript tradition: ten centuries of book arts in Indiana University collections | year= 2010 | publisher= Indiana University Press | page= | isbn= 978-0-253-35377-1| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=lIY0oAd6Y40C&pg=PA132 }}</ref> It has been suggested<ref name="Schick" /><ref name="Gruber"/> that Hafiz Osman's ''hilye'' design might have been inspired by the celebrated [[#Hilye-i Şerif|Hilye-i Şerif]], which in turn was based on the possibly spurious hadith according to which Muhammad has said "... Whoever sees my hilye after me is as though he has seen me... ". If so, a ''hilye'' might have been meant to be ''not read'' but seen and contemplated, because it is really an image made of plain text.<ref name="Schick" />
The standard Hilye-i Şerif composition has been followed by calligraphers since its creation in the late 17th century. Some examples from the 19th century and two made by Hafiz Osman can be seen below. <gallery class="center"> File:Hilye (1692) by Hâfız Osman (1642 – 1698.jpg|Hilye by Hafiz Osman Efendi (1642–1698) Hilye-i serif 5.jpg|Hilye by Hafiz Osman Efendi (1642–1698) Hilye-i serif 7.jpg|Hilye by Mehmed Tahir Efendi (d. 1848) Hilye-i serif 4.jpg|Hilye (1848) by Kazasker Mustafa İzzet Efendi (d. 1876). Hilye Niyazi Efendi 1853.JPG|Hilye (c. 1853) by Niyazi Efendi (d. 1882) </gallery> However, deviations from the standard model do occur and many innovative designs have been produced as well.<ref name="DermanN.Y.)1998"/> <gallery class="center"> Hilye Abdulkadir Surki Efendi.JPG|Hilye (19th century). Circling around the name of Muhammad, is a five-fold repetition of the phrase, "''Inna Allah ala kull shay qadir''," meaning "For God hath power over all things." Hilye with relics.JPG|Hilye combined with blocks of text in the form of famous [[Relics of Muhammad]]. 19th century, Ottoman Turkey. Black-and-white reproduction. Hilye in free form (18th century), by Esma Ibret Hanim.jpg|Hilye in free form (18th century). Hilye-i Serife Sadberg.Jpeg|Hilye in free form (18th century). Rose Hilye.jpg|Hilye in the shape of a pink rose (18th century). </gallery>
==Popularity of the graphic form== [[File:Hilye with side panels 1718.jpg|thumb|left|A ''hilye'' from 1718, similar to a Christian [[triptych]]. The middle panel is topped with a crown carving. The side panes list the [[Names of God in Islam|99 names of Allah]].]] There are several reasons given for the popularity of graphic ''hilyes''.<ref name="Erdogan"/><ref name="Yazar"/> Islam prohibits the depiction of graphic representations of people that may lead to idols. For this reason, Islamic art developed in the forms of calligraphy, miniatures and other non-figurative arts. In miniatures, Muhammad's face was either veiled or blanked. Because of the prohibition on drawing the face of Muhammad, the need to represent Muhammad was satisfied by writing his name and characteristics.
Many authors have commented that another reason is the affection that Muslims feel for Muhammad, which leads them to read about his physical and moral beauty.<ref name="Erdogan"/><ref name="Yazar"/> The (apocryphal) hadith that those who memorize his ''hilye'' and keep it close to their heart will see Muhammad in their dreams would have been another reason. Muslim people's love for Muhammad is considered to be one of the reasons for the display of ''hilye'' panels at a prominent place in their homes (see [[#Graphic art form section|Graphic art form section]] below).
Hakani has said in his poem that a house with a ''hilye'' will be protected from trouble. Another motivation would have been the hadith given by Hakani in the Hilye-i Şerif, which states that those who read and memorize Muhammad's ''hilye'' will attain great rewards in this and the other world, will see Muhammad in their dreams, will be protected from many disasters, and will receive Muhammad's esteem.
In the "sebeb-i te'lîf" ve "hâtime" section of the ''hilye'', the writer gives the reasons to write the ''hilye''. Hakani wrote that his reason was to be worthy of Muhammad's holy intercession (''shefaat'') on doomsday and to receive a prayer from willing readers. Other ''hilye'' writers express, usually at the end of the ''hilye'', their desire to be commended to the esteem of Muhammad, the other prophets, or the four caliphs. One ''hilye'' writer, Hakim, wrote that he wishes that people will remember Muhammad as they look at his ''hilye''.<ref name="Erdogan"/>
Hakani's Hilye-i Şerif has been an object of affection to many Turkish people. His poem has been copied on paper as well as on wooden panels by many calligraphers and has been read with the accompaniment of music in [[Mawlid]] ceremonies.<ref name="derman"/><ref name="poyraz">{{cite journal| author= Poyraz, Yakup| title= Hâkim Seyyid Mehmed Efendi'nin "Nazire-i Hilye-i Hâkanî" Adlı Eseri | journal= Turkish Studies | issue= 2/3 | pages= 449–484 | year= 2007 | url= | language=Turkish}}</ref>
===Non-Ottoman forms=== {{Muhammad}} As an art form, ''hilye'' has mostly been restricted to Ottoman lands. A small number of instances of ''hilye'' panels were made in Iran,<ref>{{cite web | title=حِليهنويسى | publisher=Encyclopaedia Islamica | author= | accessdate=2012-01-20 | url=http://www.encyclopaediaislamica.com/madkhal2.php?sid=6490 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140524004312/http://www.encyclopaediaislamica.com/madkhal2.php?sid=6490 | archivedate=2014-05-24 | df= }}</ref> and they reflect a Shiite adaptation of the form: there is a Persian translation below the Arabic text and the names of the [[Twelve Imams]] are listed. In the 19th century, some Iranian ''hilyes'' combined the traditional ''hilye'' format with the Iranian tradition of pictorial representation of Muhammad and Ali.<ref>See [http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Hilye_Iran_19th_c_with_image.JPG this image] for an example.</ref><ref name="oleg">{{cite journal| title= The Story of Portraits of the Prophet Muhammad| author=Grabar, O | journal= Écriture, Calligraphie et Peinture | issue= | year=2003 | pages=19–38 }}</ref>
There are contemporary exponents of the art outside this region, such as the [[Pakistan]]i calligrapher [[Rasheed Butt]] and the American calligrapher [[Mohamed Zakariya]].<ref name="Ernst2004"/>
===Traditions=== In Turkey, giving a ''hilye'' panel as a marriage gift for the happiness of the union and safety of the home has been a tradition that is disappearing.<ref name="derman"/> Covering such panels with sheer curtains was part of the religious folklore in Istanbul households.<ref name="derman"/>
Since Osman's time, every Turkish calligrapher has been expected to produce at least one ''hilye'', using the three ''muhaqqaq'', ''thuluth'' and ''naskh'' scripts.<ref name=Ali8/> It is a common tradition for masters of calligraphy to obtain their diploma of competency (''icazetname'') after completing a ''hilye'' panel as their final assignment.<ref name="derman"/>
The art of ''hilye'' flourishes in Turkey. Contemporary artists continue to create ''hilyes'' in the classical form as well as to innovate. Modern ''hilyes'' maintain the essence of a ''hilye'', even while the appearance of the elements of the ''hilye'' is customized or calligraphy is used to create abstract or figurative works.<ref>{{cite web| title=Conoscere la Turchia a Roma | publisher= Piu Culture | url= http://www.piuculture.it/2011/10/conoscere-la-turchia-a-roma/ | accessdate= 2012-02-23 }}</ref> Contemporary ''hilyes'' are exhibited in major exhibitions in Turkey as well as outside the country.<ref>{{cite web| title= Vatican to host Turkish exhibition at Cancellaria | publisher= Hürriyet Daily News | url= http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/default.aspx?pageid=438&n=vatican-to-host-turkish-exhibition-at-cancellaria-2011-09-29 | accessdate=2012-01-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| title= Masterpieces of calligraphy art on view at Yıldız Palace | publisher= Hürriyet Daily News | url= http://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/masterpieces-of-calligraphy-art-on-view-at-yildiz-palace.aspx?pageID=238&nID=6906&NewsCatID=385 | accessdate=2012-01-23}}</ref>
==Theological opinion== According to the Süleymaniye Vakfı, a [[Salafi]] influenced religious foundation in Turkey that publishes religious opinions ([[fatwa]]), ''hilye'' panels are works of art, but hanging them in the home has no religious value. That is, they provide no merit to those who hang them or carry them on their persons, and those who do not possess them have no deficit.<ref>{{cite web| title= Hilye-i Şerif nedir? Bunu üzerimizde taşımak sevap mıdır? | author=Süleymaniye Vakfı | date= 3 March 2011 | url= http://www.fetva.net/yazili-fetvalar/hilye-i-serif-nedir-bunu-uzerimizde-tasimak-sevap-midir.html| accessdate=2012-01-19 | language = Turkish }}</ref>
==A key hilye in poetry: Hilye-i Şerif== {{Wikisource|1=Translation of an excerpt from the "Hilya-i Sharifa"|2=Hilye-i Şerif}} ''[[Hilye-i Şerif]]'' ("The Noble Description", 1598–1599) by [[Mehmet Hakani]], consisting of 712 verses, lists Muhammad's features as reported by Ali (see quotation in the [[#Origins|Origins]] section above), then comments on each of them in 12-20 verses.<ref name="Gibb">{{cite book| title= A history of Ottoman poetry, Volume 3| author= Elias John Wilkinson Gibb| publisher= Luzac | year=1904 | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=MSxkAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA193}}</ref> Although some have found it to be of not great poetic merit, it was popular due to its subject matter.<ref name="Gibb"/> The poem is significant for having established the genre of ''hilye''. Later ''hilye'' writers such as [[Cevri İbrahim Çelebi|Cevri]], [[Nesati]] and [[Süleyman Nahifi|Nafihi]] have praised Hakani and stated that they were following in his footsteps.<ref name="Erdogan"/> The poem contains several themes detailed below that underscore the importance of reading and writing about the attributes of Muhammad.
In his ''hilye'', Hakani mentions the following hadith, which he attributes to Ali:<ref name="Erdogan"/> A short time before Muhammad's death, when his crying daughter Fatima said to him: "Ya Rasul-Allah, I will not be able to see your face any more!" Muhammad commanded, "Ya Ali, write down my appearance, for seeing my qualities is like seeing myself." The origin of this hadith is not known. Although probably [[apocryphal]], it has had a fundamental effect on the development of the ''hilye'' genre. This hadith has been repeated by most other ''hilye'' writers.<ref name="Yazar"/>
Hakani states another hadith, also attributed to Ali. This hadith of unknown origin is said to have been in circulation since the 9th century<ref name=Soucek>{{cite journal |author=Soucek, Priscilla |year= 2000 |title= The Theory and Practice of Portraiture in the Persian Tradition |journal= Muqarnas |volume= 17 |issue= |pages= 97–108 |publisher= |doi= 10.1163/22118993-90000008|pmid= |pmc= |url= http://cmes.hmdc.harvard.edu/files/Roxburgh_Reading1.pdf |accessdate= }}</ref> but is not found in the reliable hadith collections.<ref name=Zakariya>{{cite journal|title=The Hilye of the Prophet Muhammad |last=Zakariya |first=Mohamed |authorlink=Mohamed Zakariya |date=2003–2004 |journal=Seasons |publisher=Zaytuna Institute |pages=13–22 |url=http://zakariya.net/resources/hilye.pdf |accessdate=August 22, 2016 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202234841/http://zakariya.net/resources/hilye.pdf |archivedate=December 2, 2010 |df= }}</ref> Repeated in other ''hilyes'' after Hakani's, this hadith has been influential in the establishment of the genre.:<ref name="Erdogan"/><ref name=Gruber132 /><ref name="Ernst2004">{{cite book |title= Following Muhammad: Rethinking Islam in the Contemporary World |last=Ernst |first= Carl W. |authorlink=Carl W. Ernst |year= 2004|publisher= UNC Press Books |location= |isbn= 978-0-8078-5577-5 |pages= 76–78 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=DOWn22EkJsQC&pg=PA77 |accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title= Hat sanatında hilye-i şerife: Hz. Muhammed'in özellikleri |last= Taşkale |first= Faruk |authorlink= |author2=Gündüz, Hüseyin |year= 2006 |publisher= Antik A.Ş. Kültür yayınları |location= |isbn= 978-975-7843-07-8 |page= 35 |pages= |url= |accessdate= | language = Turkish, English }}, [http://www.faruktaskale.com/hilye-i-serife-the-charactrestics-of-the-prophet-muhammed copy on author's website] {{en icon}}</ref>
{{quotation|For him who sees my ''hilye'' after my death, it is as if he had seen me myself, and he who sees it, longing for me, for him God will make [[Jahannam|Hell]] prohibited, and he will not be resurrected naked on the [[Qiyamah|Day of Judgement]].}}
Hakani's ''hilye'' includes a story about a poor man coming to the [[Abbasid]] [[Caliph]] [[Harun al-Rashid]] and presenting him a piece of paper on which Muhammad's ''hilye'' is written. Al-Rashid is so delighted to see this that he regales the dervish and rewards him with sacs of jewelry. At night, he sees Muhammad in his dream. Muhammad says to him "you received and honored this poor man, so I will make you happy. God gave me the good news that whoever looks at my ''hilye'' and gets delight from it, presses it to his chest and protects it like his life, will be protected from hellfires on Doomsday; he will not suffer in this world nor in the other. You will be worthy of the sight of my face, and even more, of my holy lights."<ref name="Erdogan"/>
It has become customary for other ''hilye'' authors that followed Hakani to mention in the introduction of their ''hilye'' (called ''havas-i hilye'') the hadith that seeing Muhammad in one's dream is the same as seeing him. The Harun Al-Rashid story has also been mentioned frequently by other authors as well.<ref name="ispirli">{{cite journal| title= Mustafa Fehmi Gerçeker'in Hilye-i Fahr-ı Âlem İsimli Eseri Üzerine | author= İspirli, S.A.| year= 2010 | journal= Turkısh Studies | issue=2 | pages= 21–36| url=http://dokuman.tsadergisi.org/dergiler_pdf/2010/2010-Agustos/7.pdf | language = Turkish }}</ref> These elements from Hakani's ''hilye'' have established the belief that reading and writing ''hilyes'' protects the person from all trouble, in this world as well as the next.

'''Infiltration Art''' is a branch of [[Intervention art|Intervention Art]] in which artists collaborate with institutions, communities, politicians, religions, museums and pop-culture figures outside of the traditional art world. Unlike other forms of intervention art, Infiltration Art seeks to create symbiotic relationships with the host institutions.
Artists whose work incorporates elements of infiltration include [[Banksy]], Christian Cummings, [[Nikki S. Lee]], [[Taryn Simon]], [[Jeffrey Vallance]], [[David Hildebrand Wilson]], [[Fred Wilson (artist)|Fred Wilson]], the Nationwide Museum Mascot Project (NWMMP).
==External links== *[http://aar.calarts.edu/cgi-bin/clsinfo?class=AR458&sem=2&year=10 The Art of Infiltration class at California Institute of the Arts.] *[http://www.dimsum.co.uk/culture/nikki-s-lee.html Profile on Nikki S. Lee by Rodrigo Maltez-Novaes], ''DimSum'' magazine, January 23, 2002. *[http://www.portlandmercury.com/visualart/nikki-s-lee-projects/Content?oid=28924 Profile on Nikki S. Lee by Chas Bowie], ''Portland Mercury'', May 1, 2003. *[http://whitehotmagazine.com/articles/2011-interview-with-jeffrey-vallance/2226 Interview with Jeffrey Vallance], ''WhiteHot Magazine'', March 2011. *[http://bombsite.com/issues/56/articles/1960 David Pagel interview with Jeffrey Vallance], ''Bomb'' magazine, Summer 1996. *[http://www.frieze.com/issue/review/popocultural/ Review of Popocultural exhibition at South London Gallery], ''Frieze Magazine'', May 1997. *[http://www.artinamericamagazine.com/reviews/banksy/ Review of Banksy exhibition at Bristol City Museum, by Helen Weaver], ''Art in America'', September 18, 2009. *[http://nationwidemuseummascotproject.org The Nationwide Museum Mascot Project (NWMMP)] *[http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/806734/oddball-museum-mascot-project-hits-the-road-bringing-guerrilla Interview with the Nationwide Museum Mascot Project], ''Blouin Artinfo'', June 1, 2012.

{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox person |name = Jennifer Lee |image = Jennifer Lee.jpg |birth_name = Jennifer Michelle Rebecchi |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|10|22}} |birth_place = [[Providence, Rhode Island]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |education = [[University of New Hampshire|University of New Hampshire, Durham]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[Columbia University]] {{small|([[Master of Fine Arts|MFA]])}} |occupation = Screenwriter, film director, playwright |employer = [[Walt Disney Animation Studios]] (2011–present) |title = [[Chief creative officer]] of Walt Disney Animation Studios |known_for = ''[[Wreck-It Ralph]]''
''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]''
''[[Zootopia]]'' |years_active = 2004–present |spouse = Robert Monn {{small|(Divorced)}} |children = 1 }} '''Jennifer Michelle Lee'''{{cite news|last=Amidi|first=Amid|title=Chronicle Books Is Releasing A Ton Of Cartoon Titles This Fall|url=http://www.cartoonbrew.com/books/chronicle-books-is-releasing-a-ton-of-cartoon-titles-this-fall-61810.html|accessdate=January 5, 2014|newspaper=[[Cartoon Brew]]|date=April 26, 2012}} (born October 22, 1971 as '''Jennifer Michelle Rebecchi'''){{cite news|last1=Perry|first1=Valerie A.|title=Legal Notices (Probate Court of the City of East Providence)|work=Providence Journal|publisher=The Providence Journal Company|date=21 January 1995|page=B-14}} This article lists various matters noticed for hearing before the probate court, of which the relevant one is as follows: "REBECCHI, JENNIFER MICHELLE, estate - Change of name to Jennifer Michelle Lee; for hearing January 24, 1995." Available via [[ProQuest NewsStand]]. is an American [[screenwriter]], [[film director]], [[playwright]], and [[chief creative officer]] of [[Walt Disney Animation Studios]]. She is best known as the writer and director of the 2013 Disney animated feature ''[[Frozen (2013 film)|Frozen]]'', for which she earned an [[Academy Award for Best Animated Feature]]. Lee is the first female director of a Walt Disney Animation Studios [[feature film]]{{cite news|last=Kit|first=Borys|title='Frozen' Director Wants to Break a Sci-Fi Blockbuster Barrier|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/frozen-jennifer-lee-disney-animation-666372|accessdate=December 31, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=December 18, 2013|quote= Lee, 42, is the first woman in the studio's history to act as a director on one of its animated features (she co-directed with Chris Buck).}} and the first female director of a feature film that earned more than $1 billion in gross box office revenue.{{cite news|last1=Flores|first1=Terry|title='Frozen's' Jennifer Lee Melts Glass Ceilings|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/awards/frozens-jennifer-lee-melts-ceilings-1201216961/|accessdate=June 16, 2014|work=Variety|publisher=Variety Media LLC|date=June 10, 2014}} ==Early life== Lee was born in October 22, 1971{{cite news|last=Stewart|first=Jill|title=Jennifer Lee: Disney's New Animation Queen|url=http://blogs.laweekly.com/arts/2013/05/jennifer_lee_people_2013.php|accessdate=December 28, 2013|newspaper=LA Weekly|date=May 15, 2013|quote=Raised in East Providence, R.I., Lee, 41, was a flute-playing band nerd who "became a cheerleader — a nerd cheerleader."}} to Linda Lee and Saverio Rebecchi, who were living in [[Barrington, Rhode Island|Barrington]] at the time;{{cite news|last=Flynn|first=Sean|title=Is it her time to shine?|url=http://www.newportri.com/newportdailynews/news/page_one/is-it-her-time-to-shine/article_a39a9415-c79a-54ac-bcf8-798ad87e0f9f.html|newspaper=The Newport Daily News|accessdate=April 3, 2014|date=February 17, 2014}} after their divorce, Lee and her older sister, Amy, lived with their mother in [[East Providence, Rhode Island]]. Both Lee and her older sister graduated from [[East Providence High School]] and the [[University of New Hampshire]]. Lee earned a bachelor's degree in English in 1992{{cite web|last=Mackin|first=Jean|title='Frozen' writer, director says UNH helped pave her way|url=http://www.wmur.com/entertainment/frozen-writer-director-says-unh-helped-pave-her-way/23914756|work=WMUR New Hampshire 9|publisher=Manchester Hearst Properties Inc.|accessdate=April 30, 2014|date=January 14, 2014}} and went to New York City, where she worked as a graphic artist in publishing; she designed audiobooks for [[Random House]]. As an adult, she began using her mother's maiden name, Lee, in a professional capacity and in January 1995, [[Name change|legally changed her last name]] from Rebecchi to Lee. ==Career== After the loss of her boyfriend at age 20, Lee became closer to her sister Amy. At around 30 years old, she entered [[Columbia University School of the Arts]] and earned a [[Master of Fine Arts]] in film.{{cite news|last=Wolfe|first=Jennifer|title=Disney Names Jennifer Lee Director Of 'Frozen'|url=http://www.awn.com/news/disney-names-jennifer-lee-director-frozen|accessdate=January 5, 2014|newspaper=Animation World Network|date=November 29, 2012}} There she met [[Phil Johnston (filmmaker)|Phil Johnston]], her future writing partner on ''[[Wreck-It Ralph]]''. Lee graduated from Columbia in 2005{{cite web|last=August|first=John|title=Episode 128: Frozen with Jennifer Lee — Transcript|url=http://johnaugust.com/2014/scriptnotes-ep-128-frozen-with-jennifer-lee-transcript|work=Scriptnotes|publisher=johnaugust.com|accessdate=March 27, 2014|author2=Aline Brosh McKenna|date=February 1, 2014}} and stayed in New York City, where she developed a background in live-action film, working as assistant director on and producer of the short film in 2004, "A Thousand Words".{{cite web|title=A Thousand Words (Full Cast & Crew)|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1601644/|publisher=IMDb|accessdate=April 21, 2014}} In March 2011, Johnston called Lee to ask her to join him at Disney Animation in [[Burbank, California|Burbank]] to help him write ''Wreck-It Ralph''. What was supposed to be a temporary eight-week writing gig eventually turned into a much longer commitment. First, she was asked to stay on until ''Ralph'' was finished. She then became involved with [[Frozen (2013 film)|''Frozen'']], initially as screenwriter and later as co-director with [[Chris Buck]]. When Lee was brought on board, she helped transition the film from an action-adventure to "more musical, with more comedy."{{cite web|last=Laporte |first=Nicole |title=How "Frozen" Director Jennifer Lee Reinvented the Story of the Snow Queen |url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3027019/most-creative-people/how-frozen-director-jennifer-lee-reinvented-the-story-of-the-snow-queen |publisher=Fast Company |accessdate=April 29, 2014 |date=February 28, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140314091751/http://www.fastcompany.com/3027019/most-creative-people/how-frozen-director-jennifer-lee-reinvented-the-story-of-the-snow-queen |archivedate=March 14, 2014 |df= }} She worked closely with the songwriters ([[Robert Lopez]] and [[Kristen Anderson-Lopez]]) in the writing of the script. ''Frozen'' gave her the opportunity to celebrate "wild and wonderful" girls like her childhood self, and her daughter, Agatha. It was also the highest-earning film with a female director in terms of domestic earnings, until surpassed by [[Warner Bros.]]' ''[[Wonder Woman (2017 film)|Wonder Woman]]''.{{cite web |url=https://blog.womenandhollywood.com/wonder-woman-is-now-the-top-female-helmed-film-at-the-domestic-box-office-f38eba286f3b |title="Wonder Woman" Is Now the Top Female-Helmed Film at the Domestic Box Office |publisher=Blog.womenandhollywood.com |date= |accessdate=2017-08-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170724160242/http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2017/07/24/wonder-woman-sequel-title-revealed.html |archive-date=July 24, 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} On May 17, 2014, Lee delivered the [[Commencement speech|commencement address]] to the class of 2014 at her alma mater, the University of New Hampshire.{{cite web|last=Record|first=Jody|title="Frozen" Screenwriter/Director Jennifer Lee '92 is UNH 2014 Commencement Speaker|url=http://www.unh.edu/news/releases/2014/03/jr19commencement.cfm|publisher=University of New Hampshire Media Relations|accessdate=May 17, 2014|date=March 19, 2014}}{{cite news|last=Lawrence|first=Mike|title='Frozen' director warms up to speaking at UNH commencement|url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20140517/NEWS04/140519189|accessdate=May 18, 2014|newspaper=New Hampshire Union-Leader|date=May 17, 2014}}{{cite news|last=Sanborn|first=Aaron|title=Oscar-winning director of 'Frozen' inspires UNH grads|url=http://www.seacoastonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20140517/NEWS/140519750/-1/NEWSMAP|accessdate=May 18, 2014|newspaper=Seacoastonline.com|date=May 17, 2014}} She revealed that she had struggled with self-doubt while growing up,{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Jennifer|title=Jennifer Lee '92 UNH Commencement Speech 2014|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TLwsrVVgeQs|publisher=University of New Hampshire|accessdate=May 17, 2014|format=Video|date=May 17, 2014}}{{rp|2:00}} and then in April of her junior year of college, her boyfriend was killed in a boating accident, after which she felt "no doubt, only grief ... and for a brief moment ... [knew] better than to waste a second doubting."{{rp|6:18}} Years later, that memory would help her overcome her initial doubt over whether she was good enough to apply to Columbia.{{rp|7:10}} At Columbia, Johnston recognized she was talented but insecure, and one day asked her to "promise ... that you'll leave it out of your work, just know that you're good enough and move on." She concluded: "If I learned one thing it is that self-doubt is one of the most destructive forces. It makes you defensive instead of open, reactive instead of active. Self-doubt is consuming and cruel and my hope today is that we can all collectively agree to ban it ... Please know, from here on out, you are enough and dare I say, more than enough." UNH then awarded her the honorary degree of [[Doctor of Humane Letters]].{{cite news|last=Anonymous|title=Honorary degrees conferred at UNH|url=http://www.unionleader.com/article/20140517/NEWS04/140519174|accessdate=May 18, 2014|newspaper=New Hampshire Union-Leader|date=May 17, 2014}} In September 2014, it was announced that Lee and Buck would co-direct a [[short film]] featuring the ''Frozen'' characters called ''[[Frozen Fever]]''. It was released in March 2015.{{cite web|title=Disney short 'Frozen Fever' coming in spring 2015, with new song|author=Gettell, O.|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-disney-short-frozen-fever-coming-in-spring-2015-20140903-story.html|date=September 3, 2014|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=September 6, 2014}} Lee was one of several Disney writers and directors who received credit for "Creative Leadership" on the 2014 film ''[[Big Hero 6 (film)|Big Hero 6]]'' and the 2016 film ''[[Moana (2016 film)|Moana]]'', and received screen credit as one of the writers who developed the story for the 2016 film ''[[Zootopia]]''.{{cite web|title=Did a Disney animated film really say that? If it's 'Zootopia,' prepare to be shocked|publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]]|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-et-mn-zootopia-production-20160304-story.html|author=Keegan, Rebecca|date=March 4, 2016|accessdate=2016-03-14}}{{cite web|title=Big Hero 6 (2014) Production Credits|publisher=[[New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/movies/movie/477628/Big-Hero-6/credits|accessdate=2016-03-17}}{{cite web|title=Moana screen credits|url=http://www.hollywood.com/movies/moana-60594396/credits/|publisher=hollywood.com|accessdate=2016-11-26}} In August 2014, ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reported that Lee's next project after ''Frozen'' would be an [[A Wrinkle in Time (2018 film)|adaptation]] of [[Madeleine L'Engle]]'s 1962 novel ''[[A Wrinkle in Time]]''.{{cite web|title='Frozen' Director Jennifer Lee to Adapt 'A Wrinkle in Time' for Disney |publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/frozen-director-jennifer-lee-to-adapt-a-wrinkle-in-time-for-disney-exclusive-1201275488/|accessdate=August 6, 2014|date=August 6, 2014}}{{cite web|title='Frozen' Scribe Jennifer Lee Signs On To Write Big-Screen Adaptation Of 'A Wrinkle In Time'|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/05/jennifer-lee-a-wrinkle-in-time_n_5652505.html|author=Jacobs, M.|publisher=[[Huffington Post]]|date=August 5, 2014|accessdate=August 6, 2014}} After the news broke, Lee tweeted: "Been in love with the book for over 30 years. Writing this script means the world to me."{{cite news|last1=Rivera|first1=Zayda|title='Frozen' director Jennifer Lee set to adapt 'A Wrinkle in Time' for Disney|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/movies/frozen-director-adapt-wrinkle-time-disney-article-1.1892875|accessdate=August 9, 2014|work=New York Daily News|publisher=Daily News, L.P.|date=August 5, 2014}} Catherine Hand, the executive producer of the [[A Wrinkle in Time (2003 film)|2003 television film version]], and Jim Whitaker produced for Disney, and [[Ava DuVernay]] directed the film, based on Lee's script. ''A Wrinkle in Time'' was released in March 2018, but Lee's removal of all Christian references from the story caused a backlash and boycott from several Christian groups, including the online film reviewing site [[MovieGuide]].{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/ava-duvernay-wrinkle-in-time-movie-1201712895/|title=Ava DuVernay to Direct 'A Wrinkle in Time' Movie Adaptation|author=McNary, Dave|date=February 23, 2016|accessdate=2016-03-14|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]}}{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2016/11/ava-duvernay-a-wrinkle-in-time-release-date-1201854261/|title=Ava DuVernay's 'A Wrinkle In Time' To Hit Theaters In Spring 2018|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|date=November 14, 2016|accessdate=November 14, 2016}} The film received mixed reviews from the critics, and despite grossing $100 million domestically, ended its run as a box-office bomb. On March 12, 2015, Disney announced that Lee and Buck would co-direct a [[Frozen 2|full length sequel]] to ''Frozen''.{{cite web|title=Disney Announces 'Frozen 2'|author=Graser, M.|url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/disney-announces-frozen-2-1201451480/|publisher=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=March 12, 2015|accessdate=2015-03-15}} ==Personal life== Lee married Robert Joseph Monn{{cite news|last1=Wilson Hunt|first1=Stacey|title='Frozen' Director Apologizes to Parents for "Let It Go"|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/frozen-director-apologizes-parents-let-756614|accessdate=July 24, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=December 12, 2014}} on May 30, 1999, at the [[Rhode Island Country Club]]{{cite news|last1=Anonymous|title=Weddings|work=Providence Journal|publisher=A.H. Belo Corporation|date=25 June 1999|page=J-10}} Available via [[ProQuest NewsStand]]. (they later divorced). They have a daughter Agatha Lee Monn{{cite news|last=Chai|first=Barbara|title=Listen to Songs From Disney's 'Frozen' and Hear How They Were Written|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2013/11/27/listen-to-songs-from-disneys-frozen-and-hear-how-they-were-written/|accessdate=January 5, 2014|newspaper=The Wall Street Journal|date=November 27, 2013}} (born in 2003), who sings the middle verse of the song "[[Do You Want to Build a Snowman?]]" in ''Frozen''. Lee and her daughter now live in the [[San Fernando Valley]] in California. ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Film !! [[File:ModernEgypt,_Khedivial_Opera_House,_BAP_25178.jpg|thumb|right|240px|The [[w:Khedivial Opera House|Khedivial Opera House]] in 1869.]] [[File:ModernEgypt, Khedivial Opera House, BAP 25803.jpg|thumb|240px|The Khedivial Opera House.]] The '''Khedivial Opera House''' or '''Royal Opera House''' ({{lang-ar|دار الأوبرا الخديوية }} / [[ALA-LC]]: ''Dār Awbirā al-Khudaywī'') was an opera house in [[Cairo]], [[Egypt]], the oldest opera house in all of Africa. It was inaugurated on 1 November 1869 and burned down on 28 October 1971.
The opera house was built on the orders of the [[Khedive]] [[Isma'il Pasha|Ismail]] to celebrate the opening of the [[Suez Canal]]. The architects [[Pietro Avoscani]] (from [[Livorno]]) and Rossi<!--need first name--> designed the building. It seated approximately 850 people and was made mostly of wood. It was located between the districts of [[Azbakeya]] and Ismailyya<!--Do we have an article on this place?--> in Egypt's capital city.
[[Giuseppe Verdi|Verdi]]'s opera ''[[Rigoletto]]'' was the first opera performed at the opera house on 1 November 1869. Ismail planned a grander exhibition for his new theatre. After months of delay due to the outbreak of the [[Franco-Prussian War]], Verdi's new opera, ''[[Aida]]'', received its world premiere at the Khedivial Opera House on 24 December 1871.
In the early morning hours of 28 October 1971, the opera house burned to the ground. The all-wooden building was quickly consumed, and only two statues made by [http://www.fineart.gov.eg/eng/cv/cv.asp?IDS=323 Mohamed Hassan] survived.
After the original opera house was destroyed, Cairo was without an opera house for nearly two decades until the opening of the new [[Cairo Opera House]] in 1988.
The site of the Khedivial Opera House has been rebuilt into a multi-story concrete car garage. The square (to the south of Al Ataba metro station) overlooking the building's location, is still called Opera Square (Meidan El Opera)
